If you care about democracy, freedom and humanity,
please read to know more about the crisis of Hong Kong.



中英版次序唔一樣啊喂記得跟番
Full withdrawal of the extradition bill
Retraction of “riot” classification of protests
An independent commission of inquiry into alleged police brutality
Amnesty for arrested protesters
Dual genuine universal suffrage

Over 3,000 lawyers marched in black in objection to the proposed extradition bill.

Over 1 million citizens marched on the streets in objection to the proposed extradition bill. The Government turned a blind eye to our demands and decided to proceed directly to the Second Reading of the proposed bill in the LegCo, circumventing any further deliberation in the Bills Committee.

Protestors occupied Harcourt Road and surrounded the Legislative Council, which successfully prevented the LegCo from proceeding to the Second Reading of the proposed bill. In response, the police deployed excessive force to disperse the peaceful protestors. Many were shot in the head with rubber bullets. Tear gas canisters were fired into crowds stuck at the entrance of Citic Tower where ventilation was poor, causing people to suffocate with tear gas.

The Government announced the temporary suspension of the proposed extradition bill. However, the mechanism of “suspension” is non-existent in Hong Kong’s laws and procedures in relation to legislating. This means that the proposed extradition bill has never been properly and formally withdrawn. On the same day, a man committed suicide in protest by jumping off the top of Pacific Place. He became the first casualty in the anti-extradition protests.

It has been over two months since the anti-extradition protests started in Hong Kong. The Civil Human Rights Front has recently organized yet another peaceful rally in Victoria Park around the vicinities of Tin Hau, during which at least 1.7 million citizens turned out at its peak, resulting in a complete gridlock in all districts between Fortress Hill and Admiralty. In spite of the heavy rain, the turnout was so massive that many citizens simply could not reach Victoria Park through the crammed streets. Despite that the police abstained from offering any assistance on crowd control to the organizers, the demonstration remained peaceful. Unfortunately, the Government remained dismissive of such overwhelming public opinion and ignored the Five Demands of the citizens. Many criticize the Government for labelling protestors as “rioters” in a poor attempt to shift public opinion against all protestors, which only served to further inflame public anger towards the Government. The massive rally on 18 June 2019 marked a sincere effort by Hong Kongers to express their demands peacefully, yet their demands remained completely ignored.


A female protester arrested at protest accused police of conducting a humiliating and unnecessary strip-search in violation of proper protocol at news conference.
建議幫呂小姐加番張相/示意圖
Over 210,000 people formed 60km of human chains across Hong Kong, standing on pavements along three main railway lines. The Hong Kong Way is to push for the five demands which the government has rejected.


Over the pass two months,

Millions of HK people have marched…
Legal professionals,
Civil servants,
And teachers.

Numerous strategies have been used…
Road occupation,
LegCo occupation,
Airport occupation,
And strike.

Heavy prices have been paid…
Arbitrary arrests,
Blindness caused by gunshot,
And suicides of 8 youngsters.

Liberate Hong Kong
The Revolution of Our Times

Starting from 12th June, the anti-extradition law movement has lasted for over 80 days with a tremendous number of Hongkongers taking part in support of the five demands. Nevertheless, the government has responded to none of them. Chief Executive Carrie Lam refused even to announce the withdrawal of the bill. Instead, she declared the bill to be “dead”, which is a term with no legal power.

Who is tearing Hong Kong society apart? Who should bear the greatest responsibility of triggering the crisis? Who made the protesters turn to violence from peace to make their voice heard?

We, Hongkongers, are fighting for our freedom and our future. Fight for freedom. Stand with Hong Kong.

replies.msg:
Two million people marched on the streets, demanding a complete withdrawal of the extradition bill. The Chief Executive Carrie Lam apologized for "causing disputes in the society" over the bill and claimed that the bill has been suspended. However, she refused to utter the word "withdraw".

Due to the uncompromising stance of the Hong Kong government, the LegCo building was surrounded by 30,000 protesters. Some forced their way into the building and occupied the city's legislature. The Five Demands of Hong Kong citizens were read out. Protesters were soon evacuated.

Chief Executive Carrie Lam made an announcement at 4am in response to the occupation of the LegCo, saying that the extradition bill "will be dead".
Carrie Lam announced that she had suspended the bill by the words "the bill is on its death bed", which carry no legal effect. In the meantime, questions about whether the bill has been withdrawn remained unanswered.



Remaining fearless in face of the threat to terminate their employment, more than 40,000 public servants attended a rally in support of the protestors and the Five Demands. Notwithstanding the tradition of political neutrality, they have decided to voice the Government’s obvious wrongs in the interests of Hong Kong.

Rallies were held in seven districts. The police fired tear gas canisters indiscriminately in residential areas, outraging the residents who joined the protestors in condemnation against the police. In the course of merely one day, the police arrested 148 people, fired at least 800 tear gas canisters and at least 140 rounds of rubber bullets and at least 20 sponge rounds. The quantity of ammunition fired on this single day outstripped that which had been fired in June and July put together. It was also revealed that the police has been firing expired tear gas canisters which contained cyanide, a deadly chemical.
A female protestor wearing a dress was arrested and savagely carried away by several male police officers with her legs facing upwards, causing her private part to be exposed to the public when her underpants were loosened.
Thousands of Hong Kong lawyers staged yet another march urging the Department of Justice not to carry out political persecution and demanding the Government to set up an independent commission to investigate and review the events in the course of two months of anti-extradition protests.

你個title寫番HK police brutality/ police brutality

A CCTV footage was released, showing that 2 months ago 3 police officers abused a 62-year-old defenseless elderly man detained in the North District Hospital with means such as punching his genitals and head. They were arrested after the footage release.

Facing multiple accusations, police for the first time confirmed that 31 arrestees detained in the San UK Ling Holding Centre were later sent to the hospital. Six of them were severely injured. Given the police abuse of an elderly man in the hospital, it is widely suspected that the injuries of those detainees were also caused by police brutality, raising public awareness of police assault on arrestees.

In a demonstration in Kwun Tong, another protester was shot in the eye by a bean bag round. Also, the expiry dates of tear gas used to disperse the crowd were wiped off. It is believed to be the police’s attempt to cover up their continuous illegal use of expired tear gas after it was discovered earlier. Meanwhile, emission of cyanide, a deadly substance, by expired tear gas was detected at the scene with a gas monitor.
During a protest in Tsuen Wan, police deployed water cannon, which could cause death, against protestors for the first time. At night, six officers pointed their guns at a group of protestors and one of them fired a shot into the sky. They even kicked down a kneeling citizen begging them not to shoot and harm anyone while pointing gun at him.

A female protester arrested at protest accused police of conducting a humiliating and unnecessary strip-search in violation of proper protocol at news conference.
Over 210,000 people formed 60km of human chains across Hong Kong, standing on pavements along three main railway lines. The Hong Kong Way is to push for the five demands which the government has rejected.

Realizing that our voices have not been heard by the Government, 500,000 people returned to the streets. At night, dozens of men in white T-shirts armed with batons stormed the Yuen Long station, violently attacked not only protesters in black T-shirts but all passengers including a pregnant woman and journalists. People called 999 and asked for help from police. No policemen arrived in 40 minutes, which is intolerable for their normal standard. 45 people were injured with one person in a critical condition. The Hong Kong Police stated that police officers arrived only 39 minutes late. However, CCTVs from stores near Yuen Long station have shown police walking past the station without arresting anyone during the riot. Apart from that, photos of police talking to armed white-clad men were taken. Still the Hong Kong Government refused to condemn the police and investigate alleged police brutality and collusion with gangsters.


呢張建議唔駛寫段落
係每張圖隔離加番發生咩事比較簡潔有力
A female protester was shot by police in the head using bean bag bullet, losing her right eye.
Police brutally beat up arrested protesters.
Police attempted to frame a protester by planting evidence into his backpack.
Police disguised as protesters and provoked violence.
Police fired tear gas inside MTR station (firing tear gas indoor is forbidden)
Police shot protesters in a distance of less than 1 meter.
